choices.text: Growth at the site following trauma
Age related changes in the teeth

questions.text: Ewing postulates concerns with which of the following:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) EWING’S POSTULATES (Relation Between Trauma and Tumour) :These postulates should be satisfied before a relationship between Trauma and New growth (Trauma and Tumour) is accepted. 1. Evidence of previous integrity of the injured part. 2. Undeniable and Adequate trauma must be proved. 3. There must be a proof of reasonable time interval between injury and appearance of tumor. 4. Disease must develop at the exact site of Injury. 5.The nature of the tumour must be proved.

questions.text: In case of Hypothermia, shivering stops at
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 32°C • Exposure to cold produces hypothermia which is defined as an oral or axillary temperature less than 35°C. • The ability of the hypothalamus to regulate temperature is completely lost below 30°C. • Ill effects are manifested in 3 stages. - In the first stage, the patient feels old and shivers and the body temperature falls. - In the second stage, shivering stops when the temperature is at or below 32°C. - In the third stage, the temperature is lowered to 27°C or even less, which if maintained for 24 hours or longer is fatal.

questions.text: In blunt abdominal trauma, commonest site of GI rupture is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Liver The liver is the most commonly injured organ in blunt abdominal trauma due to its size, location, and consistency. Positioned in the upper right quadrant of the abdomen, the liver is partially protected by the rib cage but remains vulnerable to trauma because of its large size and relatively fixed position. The liver’s soft parenchyma and high vascularity make it prone to rupture and bleeding in cases of blunt force. Injuries to the liver can lead to significant hemorrhage and are a major concern in managing abdominal trauma. Incorrect Options: B. Duodenum The duodenum is relatively well-protected due to its retroperitoneal location and its proximity to the spine, which provides support against direct impact. While duodenal injuries can occur in blunt abdominal trauma, they are much less common than liver injuries and often result from severe force or deceleration injuries, making this option incorrect. C. Jejunum The jejunum, being part of the small intestine, is more mobile and less likely to sustain damage in blunt abdominal trauma compared to the liver. Injuries to the jejunum typically occur from compression forces or deceleration injuries, such as seatbelt-related trauma, but they are less frequent overall. D. Transverse colon The transverse colon is also less commonly injured in blunt abdominal trauma. Its location and mobility within the abdominal cavity reduce its likelihood of rupture compared to the liver. Injuries to the colon often occur with penetrating trauma rather than blunt force.

questions.text: Minimum air resulting in fatal air embolism is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 100 ml. Air embolism occurs when a significant volume of air enters the bloodstream, blocking the normal flow of blood and causing severe complications. The minimum volume of air that can cause a fatal air embolism is 100 ml. When air enters the venous circulation, it travels to the right side of the heart and then to the pulmonary arteries, where it obstructs blood flow to the lungs. This obstruction can lead to severe hypoxia, cardiovascular collapse, and eventually death. The heart is unable to pump effectively due to the air obstruction, leading to impaired oxygen delivery to vital organs. The rate of air entry and the location of the embolism are also critical factors; rapid introduction of air at this volume can overwhelm the body's compensatory mechanisms, resulting in fatal outcomes. Incorrect Options A. 50 ml While 50 ml of air in the bloodstream can cause symptoms such as chest pain, dyspnea (difficulty breathing), and hypotension, it is generally not sufficient to cause death in most cases. However, in rare instances where air enters sensitive areas such as the coronary arteries or cerebral circulation, even smaller volumes can be dangerous. This option underestimates the minimum volume required for fatality in most scenarios. C. 150 ml Although 150 ml of air is more than enough to cause a fatal air embolism, this value exceeds the minimum threshold. Fatal outcomes are possible with 100 ml of air, making this option incorrect when considering the smallest volume necessary for a lethal embolism. D. 200 ml A volume of 200 ml of air would almost certainly result in death, but this value is significantly higher than the minimum required for fatality. The correct threshold is 100 ml, so this option is incorrect as it overestimates the minimum lethal volume.

choices.text: Involves superficial layers of skin alone
Caused by contact with a rough surface
Direction of application of force can be found out

questions.text: What is the wrong statement about abrasion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pointed object cannot cause it • An abrasion is destruction of the skin, which involves only superficial layers of skin, i.e., only epidermis. • It is a two dimensional injury - only length and breadth. • It bleeds less and does not form scar after healing. • A scratch can be produced by the tip of a knife or any pointed object. • Direction can be made out by the heaped up epithelium at the end.

questions.text: Damage to whole skin is Dupuytren’s
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 4th degree burns. 4th degree burns are characterized by damage that extends through the entire skin, including the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissues. In some cases, the injury may also involve underlying structures such as muscles, tendons, and bones. These burns result in complete destruction of the skin, leaving the area blackened, charred, or leathery. The lack of sensation in the affected area is due to the destruction of nerve endings. Such burns require extensive medical intervention, including surgical debridement, skin grafting, and, in severe cases, amputation. The term "Dupuytren’s contracture" is associated with severe burns causing scarring and fibrosis, potentially leading to functional impairments. Incorrect Options: A. 2nd degree burns 2nd degree burns, also known as partial-thickness burns, affect the epidermis and part of the dermis. They are characterized by redness, blistering, and significant pain. These burns do not extend through the entire skin and are less severe compared to 4th degree burns, making this option incorrect. B. 3rd degree burns 3rd degree burns, or full-thickness burns, involve the complete destruction of the epidermis and dermis but do not typically extend into the subcutaneous tissues or deeper structures like 4th degree burns do. They result in a waxy, white, or charred appearance but are less extensive than 4th degree burns. D. 5th degree burns 5th degree burns involve even deeper tissue destruction, extending beyond the skin and muscles to involve the bones. These burns are rarely survivable and are not commonly classified in routine burn assessments. The description in the question does not correspond to such extensive damage, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: A man fell from 35 feet height. Eye witnesses say that he fell on his feet. Which of the following injuries will confirm this fact?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ring fracture + lumbar spine injury • Ring Fracture is a type of fissured fracture that encircles the base of the skull around the foramen magnum, usually running 3–5 cm outside the foramen magnum at the back and sides of the skull, passing forward through the middle ears and roof of the nose. Such types of fractures are usually noticed in the following cases: 1. Fall from a height on to feet or buttocks, when the force of fall is transmitted upwards through the spinal column. 2. Vault of skull being driven against the spine by falling of heavy load over the vertex or fall from a height on the head or heavy blow over the vertex. 3. Violent twisting of the head on the spine, shearing the vault from the base. 4. A heavy blow directed underneath the occiput or chin causing the fracture by violently lifting the skull from the spine and thereby breaking it away from its basal attachment • Fractures of the thoracic and lumbar spine may result from high-energy trauma, such as a: - Car or motorcycle crash - Fall from height - Sports accident - Violent act, such as a gunshot wound

questions.text: The depth may be more than the length of the blade in case of stab wounds over the
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Abdomen. In the case of stab wounds to the abdomen, the depth of the wound can exceed the length of the blade due to the compressibility and flexibility of abdominal tissues and organs. The abdomen contains a mix of solid organs (such as the liver and spleen) and hollow structures (like the stomach and intestines), which can shift and compress under pressure. When a stabbing force is applied, the blade may be pushed deeper into the abdominal cavity as the tissues and organs accommodate the movement. Additionally, the curved anatomy of the abdominal wall and the possibility of the blade being manipulated or thrust with greater force contribute to the increased depth of penetration. This characteristic makes abdominal stab wounds particularly dangerous and challenging to assess, as the external wound may not fully indicate the extent of internal damage. Incorrect Options A. Head The head is composed of rigid structures like the skull, which limit the penetration depth of a blade. While injuries to the scalp may be deep, the hard cranial bones prevent the depth of a stab wound from exceeding the length of the blade. This makes the head an unlikely site for such a phenomenon. B. Chest Although the chest wall is more flexible than the head, it contains protective structures like ribs and the sternum, which limit the depth of stab wounds. The pleural cavity and lungs are also less likely to compress significantly to allow the depth to exceed the blade’s length. Hence, this option is incorrect. D. Limbs The limbs consist of muscles, bones, and connective tissues that offer resistance to penetration. While stab wounds to the limbs can cause significant damage, the compressibility of tissues in the limbs is less than that of the abdominal cavity, making it rare for the depth of the wound to exceed the length of the blade.

questions.text: Least dispersion of pellets are seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Full choke. A full choke is a type of shotgun barrel constriction that creates the tightest pattern of pellet dispersion. The choke works by narrowing the barrel's exit diameter, causing the pellets to stay closer together over longer distances. This design results in a dense pellet grouping, which is ideal for shooting targets at longer ranges, as it minimizes dispersion and increases accuracy. The least dispersion of pellets occurs with a full choke because its constriction maximizes pellet cohesion, reducing the spread compared to other choke types. This feature makes it suitable for hunting or shooting scenarios where precision at extended ranges is essential. Incorrect Options: B. ¾ choke A ¾ choke provides slightly less constriction than a full choke, resulting in a wider pattern of pellet dispersion. While it still offers good accuracy and tighter grouping than more open chokes, the dispersion is greater than that seen with a full choke, making this option incorrect. C. ½ choke A ½ choke has moderate constriction, leading to a noticeable increase in pellet dispersion compared to a full choke. This choke is commonly used for mid-range shooting, as it balances pattern density and spread. However, it does not achieve the tight grouping characteristic of a full choke, making it incorrect. D. ¼ choke A ¼ choke has the least constriction among the listed options, resulting in the widest pellet dispersion. It is best suited for short-range shooting or scenarios where a broad pattern is desirable. This wide spread makes it the opposite of a full choke, rendering it incorrect for the least dispersion of pellets

questions.text: Domain of ballistics concerned with forensic pathologist is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Terminal Forensic ballistics: It is the science dealing with the investigation of firearms, ammunition and the problems arising from their use. • Proximal/Interior/Internal Ballistics: Physiochemical phenomenon from the time of detonation till the projectile leaves the barrel. • Exterior/External Ballistics: Study of the projective from the time it leaves the barrel till it reaches the target. • Terminal/Wound Ballistics: Study of effect of the projectile on the target (Study of wound)

questions.text: Pugilistic attitude is due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Coagulation of protein • Pugilistic attitude is also known as Boxing attitude or fencing posture or defence attitude. • It is due to heat stiffening, i.e., coagulation of muscle proteins, which causes contraction. • Seen in both in ante-mortem and post-mortem burns. • It occurs whether the person was alive or not at the time of burns. • Heat stiffening is due to exposure of the body to temperature above 650C. • It is seen in those dying due to bums and sudden immersion in boiling liquid. • In heat stiffening, body assumes a posture of generalized flexion. The body is flexed at all the joints except over the back.

questions.text: Most common organ damaged in air blast injury is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ear drum • In case of air blast, the most common injury is tympanic membrane rupture. Damage to cochlea is more frequent. Lung is the second common organ to be affected (Blast Lung). Liver is least common to injure. • The injuries are more serious in Immersion (under water) blast than air blast. Tympanic membrane is ruptured in case of complete submersion. Otherwise most common organ to be injured is the gastrointestinal tract. Injury to lung is less common. • Solid blast refers to wave energy that spreads through a rigid structure. Most common injuries are skeletal fractures. Fracture of legs and vertebrae is more common. GIT damage is more common than Lungs.

questions.text: Sub-dural haemorrhage is common in case of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above. Subdural hemorrhage is a type of brain injury that occurs when blood accumulates between the dura mater and the arachnoid layer of the brain, often due to trauma. This condition is common in elderly people, child abuse cases, and alcoholics for different reasons, which is why all of these groups are included in the answer. Elderly people often have more fragile blood vessels and a reduced ability to compensate for changes in brain structure, making them more susceptible to subdural hemorrhage, even after minor falls or trauma. Child abuse can lead to subdural hemorrhages, especially in cases of shaken baby syndrome, where vigorous shaking causes tearing of the brain's blood vessels. Alcoholics are at an increased risk due to the effects of chronic alcohol use, which can lead to brain atrophy, thinning of the dura, and increased likelihood of falls or accidents. Alcoholism also affects blood clotting, making individuals more susceptible to hemorrhages. Incorrect Options: A. Elderly people While elderly individuals are more prone to subdural hemorrhages due to their age-related vulnerabilities, this option only addresses one group. The correct answer must account for all groups mentioned in the question, not just the elderly. B. Child abuse Subdural hemorrhages are indeed common in cases of child abuse, particularly in shaken baby syndrome, but this option does not encompass all possible causes listed in the question. It is incomplete without considering the elderly and alcoholics. C. Alcoholics Alcoholics are at higher risk for subdural hemorrhages, but similar to the previous options, this does not fully answer the question, which asks for the most common causes across multiple groups. This option is also incomplete without including the elderly and child abuse cases.

questions.text: Antemortem abrasions can be confused with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ant bite marks • Antemortem abrasions can be confused with erosion of the skin produced by ants, excoriation of skin by excreta, pressure sores, drying of the skin etc. • Eczema is a condition where patches of skin become inflamed, itchy, red, cracked, and rough. Blisters may sometimes occur. • In case of Joule burn there is an appearance of an areola or pale halo around the electric mark. It occurs at the periphery of electric lesion in form of blanched area. This halo occurs due to arteriolar spasm from direct effect of current on vessel wall musculature. • In case of chemical burns there will be distinctive stains, eschars – moist and soft, slough away readily.

questions.text: On 4th day the colour of a bruise is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Brown. On the 4th day following an injury, a bruise typically appears brown in color. This occurs as part of the natural healing process. Initially, a bruise appears red due to fresh blood pooling under the skin, then transitions to blue or purple as the blood begins to break down. By the 4th day, the blood in the bruise has started to break down into compounds like biliverdin and bilirubin, which are green and yellow pigments, respectively. The brown color signifies the final stage of healing, where the body has processed and cleared the broken-down blood cells. Incorrect Options: A. Red A bruise appears red within the first few hours to a day, as fresh blood from the injury pools beneath the skin. The red color is due to the presence of oxygenated blood. However, by the 4th day, the red color would have faded and transitioned to brown as part of the healing process. B. Green A bruise can appear green as it begins to heal, typically around the 3rd or 4th day. The green color results from the presence of biliverdin, a pigment formed when hemoglobin in red blood cells breaks down. While the bruise may still have some green hues around day 4, the dominant color is usually transitioning to brown by this stage. C. Blue A bruise appears blue or purple in color within the first 1 to 2 days after the injury. This color is due to the deoxygenated blood pooling beneath the skin. By the 4th day, the bruise would no longer primarily appear blue, as the blood is being broken down and the healing process is progressing towards brown.

questions.text: Which fracture may be seen in only young adults due to a blunt force impact
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Diastatic • Separation of the sutures by blunt force impact can occur only in young persons (before cranial sutural closure). Once the sutures are closed completely, diastatic (sutural) fracture will not occur. • Gutter Fracture is the name used to indicate a furrow in the outer table of the skull, ordinarily the result of a glancing blow by a missile from a rifled firearm. These are frequently accompanied with comminuted depressed fractures of the inner table of the skull. • Pond or Indented fractures may be seen in infants where the skull is elastic and usually is produced by forcible compression of the skull by obstetric forceps or impact against some protruding flat object. Fissured fractures may be seen around the periphery of the dent. • Perforating fractures are nothing but wound of entry and wound of exit, usually seen in case of bullet injury.

questions.text: Scab or crust of abrasion appears brownish black in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 4-7 days. A scab or crust from an abrasion typically appears brownish-black around 4 to 7 days after the injury. This happens as the wound begins to heal and blood coagulates at the surface, forming a protective scab. As the scab dries and blood cells break down, it takes on a brownish-black color due to the presence of dried blood and other debris from the wound. This stage is part of the body's natural healing process, and the scab provides a protective layer while the underlying tissue regenerates. Incorrect Options: A. 12-24 hours Within the first 12-24 hours after an abrasion, the wound is still in the early stages of healing. During this period, a scab may start to form, but it typically appears reddish or moist, not brownish-black. The brownish-black color occurs later as the blood dries and the scab matures. B. 2-3 days In the 2-3 day window, the scab may begin to harden and darken, but it usually does not yet reach the brownish-black color. The wound is still in the process of clotting and drying, and the scab color is often more reddish or darker in hue, but not fully brownish-black. D. After one week By the time one week has passed, the scab is typically in the later stages of healing. It may have started to fall off or be replaced by new skin beneath, so it would not typically still be brownish-black. At this point, the scab may be lighter in color, and new tissue growth is evident, making this option inaccurate for the timeframe of a brownish-black scab.

questions.text: One of the following is the first enzyme to be released at the site of wound
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ATP-ase Sequence of enzymes/biochemical markers rising after injury: • Tissue cathepsin (5-10 min) • Seretonin (10 min) • Histamines (20-30 min) • Esterase and ATPase (within 1 hour) • Aminopeptidase (2 hours) • Acidphosphatase (4 hours) • Alkaline phosphatase (6 hours)

questions.text: The callus is visible on X-ray at
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 3 weeks Healing of a fracture (Age of a Fracture): • 12-24 Hours : Clotting of hematoma • 7 Days : Formation of new vessels, Fibroblasts are seen • 10 Days : Fibroblasts lay down reticulin and collagen • 10-14 Days : Hematoma get absorbed • 2 Weeks : Callus formation • 3 Weeks : Callus visible on X-ray • 1 Month : Obliteration of periosteal callus gap • 2 Months : Callus is formed into hard bone

questions.text: Which of the following is most characteristic of concussion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Transient amnesia and unconsciousness • Cerebral concussion is a state of temporary unconsciousness immediately following head injury, and is always followed by amnesia, and tends to spontaneous recovery. • Pre-traumatic (retrograde) and post-traumatic (antegrade) amnesia may be present. • Usually, the duration of retrograde amnesia is quite brief, while the duration of posttraumatic amnesia is more variable (lasting seconds to minutes), depending upon the injury. In severe concussion, the muscles are flaccid, pupils are dilated and non-reacting, pulse is weak and slow and respiration is shallow.

questions.text: In head injury bleeding from middle ear is suggestive of fracture of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Middle cranial fossa In case of fractures of the base of the skull, • Fracture of the anterior cranial fossa clinically manifested with bleeding from nose/mouth or/and CSF rhinorrhoea, and Raccoon eye. • Fracture of the middle cranial fossa clinically manifested as bleeding from the ear and Battle’s sign (Reddish discoloration on mastoid region). • Fracture of the posterior cranial fossa clinically manifested as boggy swelling over upper nape of the neck.

choices.text: Fall of heavy object on the head

questions.text: The cause for ring fracture is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above. A ring fracture refers to a type of skull fracture that involves the base of the skull, particularly around the foramen magnum, where the spinal cord connects to the brain. It is a serious injury that typically results from high-impact trauma to the head or neck. All of the above options—fall from height on feet, fall of heavy object on the head, and blow on the chin—can cause sufficient force to result in a ring fracture. Fall from height on feet: The impact force from a fall, especially when landing on the feet, can travel up the spine and reach the skull, leading to a ring fracture. Fall of heavy object on the head: A heavy object falling directly on the head creates a concentrated force that can cause damage to the base of the skull. Blow on the chin: A forceful blow to the chin can transmit energy upward through the jaw and neck, potentially causing a ring fracture at the base of the skull. Incorrect Options: A. Fall from height on feet While this option can indeed lead to a ring fracture, it is not the only cause, which is why it doesn't fully answer the question. Other traumatic events like a heavy object falling on the head or a blow to the chin can also cause this type of fracture. Therefore, it is incomplete. B. Fall of heavy object on the head This option is also a valid cause of a ring fracture, but like the previous one, it doesn't encompass all possible mechanisms of injury. While a heavy object falling on the head can create sufficient force for a ring fracture, it is not the sole cause. C. Blow on the chin A blow to the chin is another valid cause of ring fractures, as the force can travel up the neck to the skull. However, it is not the only possible cause of such fractures, and as such, this option is incomplete.

questions.text: Retraction ball necrosis is associated with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Diffuse axonal injury • Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a clinical condition in which there is diffuse injury of the axons with immediate loss of consciousness and coma of more than 6 hours. o In mild DAI, there is coma for 6-24 hours. o In moderate DAI, there is coma for more than 24 hours, but there are no signs of brainstem dysfunction. o In severe DAI, there is coma of more than 24 hours with brainstem signs. • It occurs in vehicle accidents in 90% of cases and due to falls and assaults in 10% of the cases. • Histologically, after 12 hours, the cut ends of the axons look club shaped (sausage) and finally appear as round balls known as retraction balls. Cerebral concussion is also known as Mild traumatic brain injury (MTBI), or Stunning or Commotio Cerebri.

questions.text: Use of Wadding in a smooth bore gun produces all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Causes fatal injuries Wads are present only in shotgun cartridges. The wads • Separate the projectiles from the propellant. • Help to obturate the bore effectively. • The air cushion wad which is impregnated with grease helps to lubricate the barrel • Prevents heat from the gun powder from fusing or distorting the pellets. • Acts as piston • Prevents expanding gases from escaping. • Allows optimum pressure to develop. The top wad/ overshoot wad is meant to keep the shots in place. The wads does not cause fatal injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used to detect the presence of primer metal components on the hands of an individual who fired the firearm?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dermal nitrate test The Gunshot residues on the hand if the person who fired a gun are derived from both primer and gun powder (propellant). Dermal Nitrate or Paraffin test or Diphenylamine test is used to detect Propellant (Nitrous compound detection). The primer contain metal compounds which can be detected by • Harrison and Gilroy Test • NAA (Neutron Activation Analysis) • FAAS (Flameless Automic Absorption Spectrometry) • TMDT (Trace Metal Detection Test) • SEM-EDX (Scanning Electron Microscope-Energy Dispersion X-Ray) – Best Method.

questions.text: Blackening and tattooing of skin and clothing can be best demonstrated by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Infrared photography Gunshot residue (GSR) on skin and blood stained cloth can be visualized by Infra-red rays. In the crime scene, if the blood is washed, the suspected area is sprayed with Luminol (3-amino pthalylhydrazide), which would make entire area glow bluish in the dark. Comparison microscope is used to examine and compare the secondary characteristics on a bullet. Ultraviolet light is used to demonstrate seminal stain and also to identify latent tattoo marks.

questions.text: All are components of black powder EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lead peroxide. Lead peroxide is not a component of black powder. Black powder, also known as gunpowder, is a mixture primarily composed of three key ingredients: charcoal, potassium nitrate (saltpeter), and sulfur. Lead peroxide, while a compound of lead and oxygen, is not used in the formulation of black powder. Black powder works by undergoing a chemical reaction when ignited, where potassium nitrate serves as the oxidizer, charcoal acts as the fuel, and sulfur helps to speed up the combustion process. Lead peroxide does not play a role in this mixture, making option B the correct answer. Incorrect Options: A. Charcoal Charcoal is one of the essential components of black powder. It serves as the fuel in the mixture, providing the carbon necessary for the reaction. When combined with the oxidizer (potassium nitrate) and sulfur, charcoal helps to produce the explosive energy in black powder. Therefore, this option is part of black powder and is incorrect as an answer. C. Potassium nitrate Potassium nitrate (saltpeter) is another crucial component of black powder. It acts as the oxidizer in the mixture, supplying the oxygen required to burn the fuel (charcoal). It plays an integral role in the combustion and explosive reaction of black powder. This option is a correct part of black powder, and therefore it is incorrect as an answer. D. Sulphur Sulfur is the third key ingredient in black powder. It helps to lower the ignition temperature of the mixture and accelerates the combustion process. Sulfur, along with charcoal and potassium nitrate, is essential for black powder to work effectively. This option is part of black powder, making it incorrect as an answer.

questions.text: Which of the following bullets leaves a visible mark, so that a person can see it.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tracer Bullet • In tracer bullet the rear portion of the bullet core is removed and the space is filled with a mixture of barium nitrate and powdered magnesium with strontium nitrate which burns during the plight of a bullet shedding red sparks. It leaves a visible mark or ‘trace’ while in flight. • In explosive bullet the bullet tip is grilled and a tiny canister containing Lead azide is inserted. On impact the bullet explodes. • In Incendiary bullet the tip of the bullet contains white Phosphorous, used to cause fire in the target (e.g., to ignite fuel tank). • Gyrojets are cartridges or miniature rockets driven by solid fuel, which produces considerable heat and smokeless gas on burning.

questions.text: Smokeless gun powder is composed of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Nitrocellulose • Smokeless powder is a type of propellant. It may be 1. Single based : Contains only Nitrocellulose. 2. Double based : Contains Nitrocellulose + Nitroglycerine 3. Triple based : Contains Nitrocellulose + Nitroglycerine + Nitroguanidine • These produce much less flame and smoke and more completely burn than black powder.

questions.text: Bullet scrapings around the wound is known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fouling • Smudging or blackening in case of firearm wounds is due to the deposition of smoke and soot. • Peppering or powder stippling or tattooing is due to the partially burnt or unburnt particles of gunpowder. • When the bullet comes out through the barrel, the metal fragments are scraped off, and these small fragments of metal from the bullet or the barrel impact the skin surface, around the wound of entry, the term ‘fouling’ is used.

questions.text: In frost bite, skin becomes hard black in about
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 2 weeks • Frost bite occurs after exposure to extreme cold (less than -2.5°C) temperature or dry cold or from direct contact with cold object (below 0°C). • In frostbite, skin becomes hard and black in 2 weeks. • It is commonly seen in mountaineering and polar expeditions. • Tissue injury results from freezing and vasoconstriction. • It usually affects the distal aspects of extremities or exposed parts of face such as nose, ears, chin and cheeks.

choices.text: Compressed air pushed in front of the current

questions.text: Lightening flash can cause injury by all of the following, Except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Compressed air pushed in front of the current • According to Spencer there are 4 factors that result in injury in a lightning flash. 1. Direct effect of high voltage current. 2. Burning by super-heated Air. 3. Effect of expanded and repelled air around the flash. 4. Compressed air pushed before the current produced by Lightning. Even individuals quite remote from the flash may sustain injuries due to the effect of compressed air. There is difference. - “Compressed air pushed before the current” and “Compressed air pushed in front of the current”

questions.text: The type of the burn that is relatively painless is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Deep • Wilson classified burns into 3 types. They are: - Epidermal - Dupuytren’s 1st and 2nd degree. These burns are very painful and heals without scar formation. - Dermo-epidermal - Dupuytren’s 3rd and 4th degree Pain and shock are greater than in first degrees burns (Most painful). - Deep - Dupuytren’s 5th and 6th degree (Relatively painless)

questions.text: The causative electrode of electric injury can be identified by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acro reaction • The Acro reaction test is applied for the identification of electric marks by demonstrating metal particles on the skin surfaces by simple colour reactions. • Current Pearls - Small balls of molten metal, derived from the electrode, may be carried deep into the tissues. It helps to identify the wound of entry. • Bone Pearls or Wax Drippings - Heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate, which is seen radiologically as typical round density foci, known as, Bone Pearls.

choices.text: Insertion of bullet into stab wound
Bullet retained in the body since a long time

questions.text: Rayalaseema phenomenon refers to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Insertion of bullet into stab wound • In contact shot, the muzzle blast and the negative pressure in the barrel following discharge may suck blood, hair, fragments of tissue and cloth fibers, several cm. back into the barrel called “back spatter”. • Rayalaseema phenomenon: A bullet stuffed into the stab wound of the victim to mislead the police. • Kennedy's phenomenon: Surgical intervention of gunshot wounds, so that proper evaluation of wounds becomes difficult. • Souvenir bullet: A bullet which is left in the body for long time. It may get surrounded by fibrous tissue. It may cause chronic lead poisoning.

questions.text: Sweating is not seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Heat stroke • In heat stroke (Heat hyperpyrexia), body temperature increases above the level of 41°C. There is absence of sweating. The term 'Thermic fever’ or ‘Sunstroke' is used when there has been direct exposure to the sun. There is failure of cutaneous blood circulation. • Heat cramps (miner's / stoker’s/fireman's cramps) is caused by rapid dehydration of body through the loss of water and salt in the sweat. Muscle cramp is due to loss of Na+ ion. There is no increase in body temperature. • Heat prostration (heat exhaustion/heat syncope/heat collapse) follows exposure to excessive heat. There is no increase in body temperature. It is due to peripheral vascular collapse. Death is due to cardiac failure.

questions.text: Berlin’s edema is associated with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Retinal injury • Berlin's edema (commotio retinae) a common condition caused by blunt injury to the eye. It is characterized by decreased vision in the injured eye a few hours after the injury. Commotio retinae is usually self limiting and there is no treatment as such. It usually resolves in 3–4 weeks without any complications and sequelae. • When an impact is imparted to a mobile head, the site of maximum cortical damage is most likely to be underneath or at least on the same side as the impact. This is so called, ‘coup lesion’. • When a moving head is suddenly decelerated as in case of a fall, though there might be a coup lesion at the site of the impact, there is usually cortical damage on the opposite side of the brain—‘contrecoup lesion’.

questions.text: In which of the following shot gun the inner diameter of the barrel is widest?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 10 bore. The 10 bore shotgun has the widest inner diameter of the barrel among the options listed. The term "bore" refers to the internal diameter of the shotgun barrel, and the larger the bore number, the smaller the diameter. In the case of the 10 bore, it has a larger diameter than the 12, 14, and 16 bore shotguns, which means it can accommodate larger pellets or more powder for greater firepower. The 10 bore shotgun is typically used for larger game hunting, where greater stopping power and wider shot patterns are required.

questions.text: Cause of death in crush syndrome is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Acute renal failure • Crush syndrome occurs if a large bulk of muscles is crushed, as in case of vehicular run-over injury or by falling masonry. • Crushing of muscles can liberate haeme and myoglobin which can enter the circulation and get excreted through the kidneys. • This can lead to Acute Tubular Necrosis. • Death may occur in a week’s time.

questions.text: Blast wind causes
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tertiary blast injury Blast injuries are divided into the following 4 categories: 1. Primary: Caused solely by the direct effect of blast overpressure on tissue. 2. Secondary: Caused by flying objects that strike people. 3. Tertiary: Caused by high-energy explosions. Displacement of air by the explosion creates a blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects; 4. Quaternary: All other injuries not included in the first three classes. These include flash burns, crush injuries, and respiratory injuries

questions.text: Callus is not formed in case of fracture of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Skull • In case of healing of skull Fracture healing occurs without the formation of visible callus. • The edges of fissured fracture stick together within a week. • The edges are slightly eroded and the inner surface of the skull may show pitting or deposition of lime salts in 14 days. • The edges become slightly smooth and bands of osseous tissue run across the fissure in 3 to 5 weeks. • If the edges are not in apposition, they become quite smooth in 3 months. • If there is much loss of bone, the gap is filled only with fibrous tissue.

questions.text: Following are the causes of death in patient with burns except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Air embolism Cause of death in burns: Immediate to within few hours • Primary shock- Neurogenic shock - due to pain • Asphyxia – inhalation of smoke, suffocation Within first 48 hours • Secondary shock – loss of fluid from burnt region 3-4 days • Toxaemia – absorption of various metabolite from burnt region 4-5 days and later • Sepsis, Gastric ulceration, Oedema of glottis, acute renal failure, Gangrene, Pulmonary embolism, ARDS, tetanus Years after • Malignant transformation of burn scar (Marjolin’s ulcer)

questions.text: Ectopic bruise is common in the region of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Eye • Ectopic bruise is also known as percolated bruise or migratory contusion. • Blood will track along the fascial planes or between muscle layers which form the least resistance and may appear where the tissue layers become superficial. E.g.: - Blunt trauma to the forehead may lead to gravitating of blood around the eye and cause black eye. - Black eye caused by the fracture of anterior cranial fossa. - Bruise in the neck in case of fracture of jaw bone. - Bruise in the thigh due to fracture of pelvis. - Fracture of femur may cause bruise over outer aspect of lower thigh. - A blow on the upper thigh may cause a bruise above the knee. - Impact over the calf may give rise to bruise over the ankle.

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in case of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hypothermia Paradoxical undressing: • It is a term for a phenomenon frequently seen in cases of lethal hypothermia. • Shortly before death, the person will remove all their clothes, as if they were burning up, when in fact they are freezing. • Because of this, people who have frozen to death are often found naked and are misidentified as victims of a violent crime. • The reason for this paradoxical behaviour seems to be the effect of a cold-induced paralysis of the nerves in the vessel walls, which leads to a vasodilatation, giving a feeling of warmth.
